t: Job 30
“But*pn now they mock at me, men*i younger than I, Whose*ld fathers I disdained to put with the dogs of my flock.
Indeed,*ld what profit*i is the strength of their hands to me? Their*ld vigor has perished.
They*ild are*i gaunt from want and famine, Fleeing*ld late to the wilderness, desolate and waste,
Who*ld pluck mallow by the bushes, And*ld broom tree roots for*i their food.
They*ld were driven out from among men,*i They*ld shouted at them as at*i a thief.
They*ild had*i to live in the clefts of the valleys, In*ild caves of the earth and the rocks.
Among*ld the bushes they brayed, Under*ld the nettles they nestled.
They*ild were*i sons of fools, Yes,*ld sons of vile men; They*ld were scourged from the land.
“And*ln now I am their taunting song; Yes,*ld I am their byword.
They*ld abhor me, they keep far from me; They*ld do not hesitate to spit in my face.
Because*ld He has loosed my bowstring and afflicted me, They*ld have cast off restraint before me.
At*ld my*i right hand*i the rabble arises; They*ld push away my feet, And*ld they raise against me their ways of destruction.
They*ld break up my path, They*ld promote my calamity; They*ld have no helper.
They*ld come as broad breakers; Under*ld the ruinous storm they roll along.
Terrors*ld are turned upon me; They*ld pursue my honor as the wind, And*ld my prosperity has passed like a cloud.
“And*ln now my soul is poured out because of my plight;*i The*ld days of affliction take hold of me.
My*ld bones are pierced in me at night, And*ld my gnawing pains take no rest.
By*ld great force my garment is disfigured; It*ld binds me about as the collar of my coat.
He*ld has cast me into the mire, And*ld I have become like dust and ashes.
“I*ln cry out to You, but You do not answer me; I*ld stand up, and You regard me.
But*ild You have become cruel to me; With*ld the strength of Your hand You oppose me.
You*ld lift me up to the wind and cause me to ride on*i it;*i You*ld spoil my success.
For*ld I know that*i You will bring me to*i death, And*ld to*i the house appointed for all living.
“Surely*ln He would not stretch out His*i hand against a heap of ruins, If*ld they cry out when He destroys it.*i
Have*ld I not wept for him who was in trouble? Has*ld not*i my soul grieved for the poor?
But*ld when I looked for good, evil came to*i me;*i And*ld when I waited for light, then came darkness.
My*ld heart is in turmoil and cannot rest; Days*ld of affliction confront me.
I*ld go about mourning, but not in the sun; I*ld stand up in the assembly and*i cry out for help.
I*ld am a brother of jackals, And*ld a companion of ostriches.
My*ld skin grows black and falls from me; My*ld bones burn with fever.
My*ld harp is turned*i to mourning, And*ld my flute to the voice of those who weep.
